awd_titl_txt: Observations of Solar Prominences with Multi-Conjugate Adaptive Optics: Using the Big Bear Solar Observatory as a Testbed for DKIST
awd_abstract_narration:
Traditional adaptive optics are effective for small targets but tend not to work as well across the whole field of view of a telescope. This means that solar telescopes, which seek to resolve small features on the Sun that can fill the field of view, have not been able to take advantage of this technology. The innovation of multi-conjugate adaptive optics (MCAO) solves this problem. MCAO is to be part of the upcoming Daniel K. Inouye Solar Telescope (DKIST). The work proposed here is to complete development of an MCAO system in the near-infrared for the Big Bear Solar Observatory (BBSO) as a prototype for DKIST. The system will be tested by conducting observations of solar prominences in two different campaigns. Lessons learned from BBSO will provide a blueprint for development of the DKIST system.

The team will complete the development of a testbed NIR-MCAO system and connect it to BBSO?s Goode Solar Telescope (GST). They will use the MCAO apparatus to feel light to GST?s Near-Infrared Imaging Spectro-polarimeter (NIRIS). NIRIS operates at wavelengths between 1.0 and 1.7 microns. The team will conduct observations of the solar disk using this system. They will also conduct observations of prominences using a prototype wavefront sensor in an effort to better understand the particular issues that arise when one attempts to conduct adaptive optics observations of prominences (called ?prominence AO?). The objective of this work is to identify unique issues within various AO regimes that DKIST will be likely to encounter, and to innovate solutions for these issues.

por.por_cntn:
Adaptive Optics (AO) is the enabling technology for modern, large aperture ground-based telescopes because it corrects the effects of atmospheric turbulence near the center of the field of view.  The backbone of AO is large format deformable mirrors than can rapidly change shape to compensate in real time for the comparably rapidly changing effects of atmospheric turbulence.  The turbulence is measured by a wavefront sensing camera and its output is used to guide the shape changes in the deformable mirror.   However, some of the most interesting dynamical effects on the Sun cover a wider field than a single DM can correct.   Sometimes flaring seems to occur everywhere in the field of view all at once, which necessitates multi-conjugate AO (MCAO).  In Big Bear Solar Observatory (BBSO), the heart of our MCAO system consists of three deformable mirrors conjugated to three different altitudes covering the ground to about 11 km above, and operating under a complex control system. The MCAO system in Big Bear is a pathbreaker for the MCAO system to come on DKIST (Daniel K. Inouye Solar Telescope).  In visible light, the BBSO system more than trebles the corrected field from about 10" to about 35", which is a major advantage because, among other things, it fully covers a large sunspot and the environs.  The primary purpose of our effort here is to expand MCAO into near infrared (NIR), which is terra incognita for solar MCAO but offers the possibility of more than doubling the corrected field over the 35" in visible light because the seeing/turbulence is Kolmorogov in character.

The visible light MCAO system in BBSO, named Clear, is a Facility Instrument in regular operation since 2019.  Our primary goal here was to extendClear into the near IR, which entailed new optical elements for MCAO and design/construction of an optical setup feeding MCAO corrected light to Focal Plane Instrumentation.  In Figure 1, we show the first ever vector magnetogram resulting from MCAO corrected solar light was fed to BBSO's Near IR Imaging Spectropolarimeter (NIRIS).  For details about this dual Fabry-Perot device see bbso.njit.edu (under Projects, GST Instruments, Instrument Specification), but basically there are two 10 cm diameter Fabry-Perot interferometers feeding light to a 2Kx2K HgCdTe, closed-cycle He cooled IR array capable of delivering a full vector field in ~30s.

 

Figure 1 shows a single chromospheric event circled in orange as seen at different altitudes in the solar atmosphere.  The three figures in the top row top row show the three components of the local vector magnetic field from 22:04 UT 16 July 2021 with the place in the field indicated in the figure.  In detail, the figure shows NIRIS V, U and Q Stokes images acquired using the strong magnetic line (Lande factor g=3) at 1.56 microns, which is one of the deepest formed photospheric lines in the solar spectrum. The Stokes V (line of sight magnetic field) image (left panel) clearly shows opposing bipolar field components (black and white patches in the orange circle), which are about to annihilate causing magnetic reconnection and field reconfiguration observed a few minutes later in the lower panel of Figure 1, which presents co-temporal on-band and off-band Halpha with the epicenter of the event marked with the orange circle. During the emergence the coherent flux system is "shredded" into small flux tubes that often assume a serpent-like shape.  

 

The second part of the work proposed is Prominence AO in which a single deformable mirror locks onto part of a prominence using a part of the Halpha light from this off-limb phenomenon as the "guide-star" (or guide-region). The wavefront sensor with 9-cm subapertures at the GST dedicated to solar prominences and performed closed-loop observations using the existing pupil-conjugate DM of the telescope. This sensor receives about 33% of the visible light available in the Coude focus. A 0.07 nm wide, high-transmission filter that is centered on the Halpha line, which removes stray light from the photosphere and makes the prominences visible in the wavefront sensor.

Figure 2 compares typical priminence observations in 10830 A light from August 5, 2022 with a 50 arc second field of view.  There is a sharp improvement between two bursts about 30 s apart taken with adaptive optics on and then off. These are the first prominence observation in which the correction is apparent to the naked eye.  

The successes here in NIR MCAO and Prominence AO show the path forward for the comparable projects planned for DKIST and is reflective the cooperation between BBSO the National Solar Observatory on this project.  In addition, these two new systems in BBSO open opportunities for upgrading instrumentation.

As well, the BBSO NIR Clear, like  nighttime NIR Gemini MCAO (GeMS) provide guidance for all.
